Remark: When defining the path of policy rate cuts, it should be borne in mind that prompt and gradual action contains macroeconomic volatility better than a tardy and hasty approach.
Significance: Panetta suggests that the ECB should cut rates gradually but steadily. This is a dovish comment, since it indicates that policymakers should consider cutting after June.

Remark: As recession risks fade, barring a major surprise, the ‘insurance’ rate hike of September 2023 may now be reversed.
Significance: Kazaks suggests that he sees the first rate cut as removing excessively restrictive policy, but doesn't indicate that further easing is necessary beyond this.

Remark: The overall direction of wages still points to deceleration, which is essential.
Significance: Lane downplays the importance of a recent data release showing that euro area negotiated wages have grown more than expected in early 2024.

Remark: I sometimes read that we should cut rates only once a quarter when new economic projections are available, and hence exclude July [...] Why so, if we are meeting-by-meeting and data-driven?
Significance: Villeroy indicates that a July cut is still on the table.

Remark: Inflation is converging to our 2% target in a sustained way, and the time is thus ripe in June to ease the monetary policy stance and start cutting rates.
Based on these data, we now consider the three interest rate cuts in 2024 as the most likely scenario.
This real-wage recovery is compatible with inflation converging to 2%.
I’m not too worried in the sense that I don’t think the trend toward lower inflation has necessarily been broken [...] but it emphasizes the need to monitor developments.
If there’s a rate cut in June, we have to wait, and I believe we have to wait till maybe September.
Significance: Nagel pushes back on the idea of two consecutive rate cuts.

Remark: We have been very transparent about the decision at the June meeting [and] we are taking a prudent approach, which would argue in favor of a reduction of 25 basis points.
We should not over-interpret, we keep confident in the disinflationary process.
Significance: Villeroy underplays the importance of unfavourable data on negotiated wages, suggesting that a June cut is effectively a done deal.

Remark: The forecast that we have for next year and the year after that is really getting very, very close to target, if not at target. So, I am confident that we’ve gone to a control phase.
We’re currently seeing a slight revival of the economy in the euro area [...] there’s reason for hope that we’ll succeed in returning to price stability without experiencing a recession.
Based on current data, a rate cut in July does not seem warranted [...] we should look very carefully at the data because there is a risk of easing prematurely.
Significance: Schnabel explicitly pushes back against a second cut in July. This is in line with her usual hawkish stance, but it is notable that she is laying out her view more clearly, and earlier, compared to other policymakers.

Remark: Unless we’ll get a big surprise, June is a reasonable, realistic moment to cut interest rates, but I can’t say what will happen after that [...] I’m open to different possibilities but I want to wait for more information.

We have said very clearly that we are data-dependent and that we are going to have a meeting-by-meeting approach [...] I think that this is the correct approach. [...] Why? Because there is a lot of uncertainty.
Significance: De Guindos refuses to indicate whether the GC will vote for a second consecutive cut in July, which suggests that this discussion is still very open-ended.

Remark: Given that inflation will be moving sideways for most of the year, you should not expect some kind of action at every meeting.
Every indicator points in the direction of a first rate cut in June, that would be our central scenario, as it looks like we could already meet our 2% inflation goal target by mid-2025.
I would prefer to remain less specific and repeat the general message that ECB Governing Council members have carried.
It’s [...] not so clear whether the developments in the US will really have a meaningful impact on the inflation outlook in the euro area.
Significance: Knot is suggesting that the risks of ECB-Fed divergence cancel each other out, and therefore the overall effect will be minimal. This is an unexpectedly dovish comment from a hawk, who might have emphasized the inflationary impact of a weaker euro over the disinflationary effect of tighter monetary policy conditions.

Member: Pierre Wunsch (Governor, National Bank of Belgium)
Remark: Higher U.S. interest rates could lead to a strong dollar and thus to imported inflation, i.e. higher prices here [...] that might lead to a slower pace at which we cut rates.
Significance: Wunsch emphasizes the inflationary risks of divergence if the ECB were to continue cutting as the Fed held rates. This suggests that there is no consensus yet on the GC about the implications of divergence.

Remark: There’s no commitment at all beyond that.
Significance: Elderson suggests the rate trajectory beyond June is open-ended.

Remark: We don’t operate in a vacuum. The Fed with the dollar is, figuratively speaking, the gorilla in the room.
Significance: Holzmann underscores that the ECB is, at least to some extent, dependent on the Fed.

Remark: If the projections stand, as we see it at the moment, I would expect the loosening of the policy stance, but still staying in the restrictive territory to make sure inflation is brought down to the 2% level.

My thinking is that there are some other interest rate cuts coming in the future, but I will restrict myself from elaborating on how many, even if I have already expressed that this year, I would expect three cuts.
